awd_titl_txt: Exploring Metal-Free Living Cationic Polymerizations via Reversible Addition-Fragmentation Chain Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthetic polymers (commonly known as plastics) are a mixture of different molecular "strings" having different lengths. While for many applications, such a mixture does not impact the physical properties of the polymer, some applications require polymers to have strings of the same length to attain specifically-desired polymer properties. The research group of Professor Wei You at the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill has discovered a new polymerization methodology for preparing polymers that have a narrow distribution of lengths. To further develop the methodology, this research seeks a better understanding of the polymerization process in order to achieve greater control of the lengths of such molecular strings.  The research also seeks to broaden the applicability of the synthesis methods to a wide range of different polymers. Education, collaboration, and outreach are integral aspects of this project. Professor You actively recruits students of underrepresented groups into his research group.  Graduate, undergraduate, and high school students receive training in cutting-edge small molecule and polymer synthetic methods, along with complex analytical techniques through engaging in this interdisciplinary research project. Professor You is actively involved in a number of outreach activities, including the UNC Science Expo (part of the North Carolina Science Festival).  This event is UNC?s single largest science outreach event, attracting approximately 10,000 participants annually. In addition, Professor You has also designed short lectures on polymer solar cells for high school students and teachers brought as part of the Climate LEAP program.

The classical living cationic polymerization achieves "living" characteristics via the equilibrium between the ionic (i.e., propagating chain end) and the covalent (i.e., resting chain end) species.  In contrast, the controlled cationic polymerization recently discovered in Professor You's laboratory proceeds through an entirely new mechanism - a cationic chain transfer mechanism, analogous to that of the conventional Reversible Addition-Fragmentation Chain Transfer (RAFT) radical polymerization. This research explores and elucidates the mechanism of this new cationic polymerization process.  The project investigates the mechanistic details of a new metal-free, protonic acid initiated and alcohol-mediated controlled cationic polymerization.  The researchers expand this unique living cationic polymerization into polymerizing various electron-rich monomers, and unveiling the roles of the applied photocatalysts in the controlled cationic RAFT polymerization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

por.por_cntn:
Goals

The objective of this proposal is to conduct a fundamental study of a new metal-free, protonic acid initiated and alcohol mediated living cationic polymerization, to expand this unique living cationic polymerization into polymerizing various electron-rich monomers, and to explore the role of the applied photocatalysts in this living cationic RAFT polymerization.

Intellectual Merit

Specifically, through this Award (three years total, including one year no cost extension), we have achieved the following (not exhaustive, only the highlights):

  1. A total of 6 publications have been published, all in high-impact journals.
  2. demonstrated the alcohol-controlled cationic polymerization of vinyl aromatic monomers bearing an electron donor group; however, this specific polymerization is generally not suitable for other cationic monomers such as vinyl ethers. Photocatalysts function as the means to create the cationic species, a role that can be assumed by using other strong acid such as triflic acid.
  3. Demonstrated, experimentally and computationally, a better control of the cationic degenerative chain transfer (DCT) polymerization can be achieved by increasing the nucleophilicity of CTA via promoting cationic chain transfer events (O < S < Se)
  4. Demonstrated a new form of orthogonal polymerizations by selective cationic RAFT control of monomers bearing a second RAFT agent which remains dormant during the cationic RAFT process, but allows a second monomer to be grafted from the pendant RAFT agents via a radical RAFT process to synthesize bottle brush polymers
  5. Discovered a new RAFT step-growth polymerization
  6. Demonstrated the versatility of RAFT step-growth polymerization in creating molecular bottle brushes

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts have been significant, including the following.

1. Research results: The fundamental understanding we have gained regarding group VI elements (O, S, and Se) to control the cationic polymerization of vinyl aromatic monomers bearing an electron donor group has inspired others to explore more use of such elements to control polymerizations. The newly discovered RAFT step-growth polymerization would offer a new method to well-controlled polymerization that would provide novel materials. The simplified method with commercially cheap monomers will further enhance the adoption of this new method by others

2. Education and training: this project has been a great opportunity to train graduate students and undergraduate students, all of whom are mentored by the postdoctoral scholar and the PI. The postdoctoral scholar has been provided numerous opportunities to hone and perfect speaking and presentation skills in both formal and informal settings. All project researchers learn new science and develop important new technologies, build networks of collaborators and contacts, learn important skills for working in interdisciplinary environments, and are thus better equipped for future careers and leadership roles in science and technology. Notably, one Hispanic undergraduate student was trained and he has joined the PI’s lab for his PhD.

3. Publication and presentation: Results obtained in this work have been published in peer reviewed journals (6 publications as of now), and the participants (students, postdoc and the PI) have given research presentations in various venues. Notably, over half of the publications have undergraduate student in the co-authorship.

4. Outreach to general public, and K-12: We have done at least two outreach activities per year (typically NC Science Fair in April and CLIMATE Leap in July).

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2022
Modified by: Wei You
